metadata.title: Single-Source-Precursor Synthesis and High-Temperature Evolution of a Boron-Containing SiC/HfC Ceramic Nano/Micro Composite

sections.text:
A boron-containing SiHfC(N,O) amorphous ceramic was synthesized upon pyrolysis of a single-source-precursor at 1000 °C in Ar atmosphere. The high-temperature microstructural evolution of the ceramic at high temperatures was studied using X-ray powder diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. The results show that the ceramic consists of an SiHfC(N,O)-based amorphous matrix and finely dispersed sp2-hybridized boron-containing carbon (i.e. ByC). High temperature annealing of ByC/SiHfC(N,O) leads to the precipitation of HfCxN1-x nanoparticles

as well as to β-SiC crystallization. After annealing at temperatures beyond 1900 ºC, HfB2 formation was observed. The incorporation of boron into SiHfC(N,O) leads to an increase of its sintering activity, consequently providing dense materials possessing improved mechanical properties as compared to those of boron-free SiC/HfC. Thus, hardness and elastic modulus values up to 25.7 ± 5.3 and 344.7 ± 43.0 GPa, respectively, were measured for the dense monolithic SiC/HfCxN1-x/HfB2/C ceramic nano/micro composite.
Keywords: polymer-derived ceramic nanocomposites; silicon carbide; hafnium carbide; hightemperature; UHTCs

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Boron is a widely used element in the field of advanced ceramics either by forming borides (e.g., HfB2, ZrB2, TiB2, NbB2 and TaB2), BN and B4C with excellent structural/functional properties at high/ultrahigh temperatures [1-3] or by acting as additives/dopants to enhance the thermal stability,[4-7] oxidation resistance,[8, 9] corrosion resistance [10, 11] as well as sintering activity of ceramics.[12-17] For instance, HfB2 and ZrB2 are reported to have unique combination of high melting point (> 3000 ºC), excellent thermal and chemical stabilities, high electrical and thermal conductivities, as well as resistance to erosion/corrosion that makes them suitable for application in harsh environment associated with atmospheric re-entry, hypersonic flight and rocket propulsion.[1, 18-20] In addition, cubic BN, B4C and TiB2 are considered as good candidates for armor or cutting tools due to their excellent mechanical properties.[21-24] Very recently, a promising strategy has been developed by Xiong’s group, i.e., incorporation of some boron into the carbon vacancies of ternary nonstoichiometric carbides (e.g., Zr0.8Ti0.2C1-x) to take advantage of both carbides and borides.[25, 26] For example, the Zr0.8Ti0.2C0.74B0.26 ceramic was demonstrated to exhibit outstanding ablation resistance several times superior than that of ZrC, ZrB2 and their composites at temperatures from 2000 - 3000 ºC.[25] J ur P re

In the field of polymer-derived ceramics (PDCs), the enhancement of high-temperature stability [4-6, 27] and resistance to oxidation/corrosion [8, 10, 11] caused by incorporation of boron has been extensively reported as well. In PDCs, the boron is introduced into the ceramics via molecular design of the preceramic precursors, which makes the distribution of boron more homogeneous and consequently the effects of boron more significant.[28-30] In our previous work, a series of dense monolithic SiC/HfC-based ceramic nanocomposites with HfCxN1-x-carbon core shell nanoparticles homogeneously dispersed within the β-SiC matrix have been prepared via a single-source-precursor approach.[31, 32] Using this method, the preceramic precursors can be tailored at the molecular level in order to obtain unique chemical/phase compositions and microstructures and consequently improved properties.[33-35] Thus, SiC/HfC-based ceramic nanocomposites exhibit excellent mechanical property profiles, enhanced laser ablation resistance, tunable electrical conductivity and promising electromagnetic absorbing/shielding efficacy.[32, 36-38] In this work, in order to further improve the structural or functional properties of the SiC/HfC-based ceramics and to study the fate and role of boron in the Si-Hf-C system, a small amount of boron was introduced into the SiC/HfC ceramics using a single-source precursor method. The synthesis process, polymer-to-ceramic transformation, hightemperature microstructural evolution as well as mechanical properties of the boron-containing SiC/HfC dense monoliths were intensively characterized and discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials preparation
sections.text:
A Hf- and B-containing single-source precursor (denoted hereafter as Hf-B-SMP10) was synthesized upon reaction of a commercially available allylhydridopolycarbosilane (AHPCS with the trade name SMP10, Starfire System Inc, USA) with tetrakis(diethylamido)hafnium (IV) (TDEAH, Sigma-Aldrich, Germany) and BH3·SMe2 (BSM, Sigma-Aldrich, Germany). The synthesis was carried out in argon atmosphere (Schlenk Technique). The weight ratio of TDEAH/SMP10 was 30/70, and the amount of BMS was calculated according to the molar ratio

The as-synthesized Hf-B-SMP10 was then ground and pyrolyzed at 1000 °C in Argon forming a black ceramic powder denoted as SHBC-1000°C. The high temperature behavior of SHBC-1000°C was studied by annealing at 1300, 1500, 1700 and 1900 °C in Argon for 5 h. Dense monoliths (denoted as SHBC-SPS) were prepared from SHBC-1000°C powder using spark plasma sintering (2200 °C, 50 MPa, 20 min in vacuum) on a FCT HP D 25/1 instrument (FCT Systeme GmbH, Frankenblick, Germany). For the sake of comparison, a SiC/HfC ceramic without boron (denoted hereafter as SHC) was prepared from Hf-SMP10 and was sintered on a SPS apparatus (Dr. Sinter 2050, Sumitomo Coal Mining Co. Ltd., Kawasaki, Japan) in Arrhenius Laboratory of Stockholm University in Sweden under the same sintering conditions. All ceramic monoliths were finally polished with 1/4 μm polycrystalline diamonds on felt cloth and subsequently machined into small blocks with the dimension of 3 × 4 × 2 mm3 for nanoindentation test.

sections.text:
The as-synthesized preceramic precursors Hf-B-SMP10 and Hf-SMP10 were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and solid-state magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MAS NMR). The polymer-to-ceramic transformation process of Hf-B-SMP10 and Hf-SMP10 was analyzed via TG/MS, which was carried out on a thermal analysis device (STA 449C Jupiter, Netzsch Gerätebau GmbH, Selb/Bavaria, Germany) coupled with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 403C Aëolos, Netzsch, Germany).

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Chemical composition
sections.text: After pyrolysis of Hf-B-SMP10 at 1000 ºC, SHBC-1000°C was obtained as an X-ray amorphous ceramic powder. The mass loss, chemical composition and empirical formula of the boron-containing ceramic (i.e., SHBC) after annealing at elevated temperatures are listed in Table 1. The Si, B and Hf content of SHBC-1000ºC were measured using ICP-AES, the remaining contents in the Table 1 were estimated according a constant atomic ratio of Si/Hf/B and the measured C, N and O content. The B and Hf content within the SHBC-1700 ºC sample was also measured using ICP-AES to be 0.57 wt.% and 15.30 wt.%, respectively, which is almost the same as the estimated value in Table 1. Therefore, no significant B and Hf loss occurs during the high-temperature thermal treatment, and the estimation is reliable. A significant mass loss of the SHBC ceramics is detected after annealing of the sample at 1500 °C due to carbothermal reactions with the release of N2 and CO.[31, 41] After the removal of N and O, there was only slight mass loss of the materials, even upon annealing at 1900 °C for 5 h in argon, indicating a promising high-temperature stability of the final product.[31]

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Characterization by Raman spectroscopy
sections.text:
Raman spectra of the SHBC ceramics are shown in Figure 3a, revealing the presence of highly disordered free carbon.[45] The G band is due to stretching vibrations of sp2-carbon in the basalplane of ideal graphitic lattice with E2g-symmetry.[46, 47] The D band is a defect-induced band, which corresponds to a graphitic lattice vibration mode with A1g-symmetry.[45, 48] Accordingly, the intensity ratio of the D band to G band [I(D)/I(G)] may be considered as a measure of the structural disordering of segregated carbon.[31, 36] The I(D)/I(G) value of SHBC-1900ºC (0.82) is almost 3 times higher than that of SHC-1900ºC (0.30), implying the highest disordering of the segregated carbon within the SHBC ceramics.[36] The D' band is also defect-induced but corresponds to a graphitic lattice mode with E2g symmetry.[28, 45, 49] The intensity of D' band in the Raman spectra of SHBC-1700ºC and SHBC-1900°C is significantly higher than that in the spectra of the SHC-1700ºC and SHC-1900ºC (Figure 3c), respectively, clearly indicating that the segregated carbon in SHBC is more disordered than that in SHC ceramics. Several reasons may lead to the increased disordering of the SHBC ceramics. One possible reason is the local structural distortion of the segregated carbon induced by B incorporation into the graphene layers.[28, 50-52] In addition, the higher disordering of the carbon phase in the ceramic nanocomposites prepared at high temperatures (i.e., 1900 °C - this composition reveals the presence of HfB2) may be also a consequence of the formation of HfB2 (upon consumption of carbon), as HfB2 is generated in processes most probably involving the segregated carbon phase in the SHBC ceramics. Thus, as mentioned above, the intensity of the D' band of the SHBC1900ºC decreases as compared with that of SHBC-1700ºC. It is considered that the boroncontaining carbon phase is involved in the conversion of HfCxN1-x into HfB2 (Figure 2).[35]
Interestingly, the D’ band in the Raman spectrum of SHC-1900ºC disappears, whereas the D' band in the Raman spectrum of SHBC-1900°C still exists (Figure 3c). This may indicate that the boron present in the segregated carbon phase of SHBC-1900°C is not fully consumed upon formation of HfB2. Indeed, based on the elemental analysis of SHBC-1900°C showing a B content of ca. 0.6 wt.% (Table 1) and assuming a full consumption of B to form HfB2, a mass

sections.heading: 3.3.4 Characterization by TEM
sections.text:
Figure 4 shows TEM micrographs of SHBC-1700°C. The SAED patterns reveal the existence of HfCxN1-x and β-SiC, which can be distinguished by their dark and light contrast, respectively. Consistent with the XRD patterns of SHBC-1700°C, no diffraction pattern related to HfB2 can be detected in the SAED. Previously reported TEM images of boron-free SHC ceramics revealed a unique microstructure with HfCxN1-x nano grains encapsulated by an amorphous carbon shell (forming a core-shell structure) embedded homogeneously within the β-SiC matrix.[31, 36] This unique microstructure can also be found in SHBC ceramics synthesized in the present study. Thus, the existence of boron in the amorphous SiHfC(N,O) ceramic does not affect the formation of the HfCxN1-x/a-C core-shell structure. Therefore, two different segregated carbon phases (carbon shell and carbon ribbon) are present within the β-SiC matrix (see Figure 4c and Figure 4d). The carbon ribbons show much higher ordering than that of the carbon shells, which is similar to the situation found in the SHC ceramics.[36] As calculated from the TEM images, the average grain size of the HfCxN1-x nanoparticles in SHBC-1700°C

As shown in Figure 7a, the 11B MAS NMR spectrum of SHBC-1000ºC shows one broad resonance with a chemical shift centered at 30 ppm, representing boron bonded to three nitrogen atoms forming a trigonal planar BN3 coordination as in hexagonal BN.[54] This is common in the Si-B-C-N system where boron is found to exhibit a strong affinity to nitrogen.[55, 56] The broad linewidth of the resonance suggests that boron is also partly coordinated by carbon, forming mixed coordination such as BN2C sites.[57] In Figure 7b, the 13C spectrum of SHBC1000ºC indicates that some of the segregated carbon atoms might be connected to nitrogen or boron, indiucing low-field shift of resonances at 140 - 150 ppm.[58] Therefore, it is considered that C-B-N mixed bonds might be present in the boron-containing segregated carbon.[28] Moreover, the high-field shift of the 11B resonances (indicating replacement of B-C bonds by B-N bonds) at 1500 and 1700 ºC suggest that, at elevated temperatures, the BN3 sites became the main coordination type of the boron atoms within the boron-containing segregated carbon.[27, 59] This behavior has also been found in previously reported SiBCN ceramics.[56, 57, 59] For instance, within the boron-rich Si-B-C-N system, the BCN phase converts into free carbon (without boron) and turbostratic BN phases after thermal treatment at temperatures beyond 1500 - 1600°C.[27]

The as-pyrolyzed amorphous SHBC-1000°C ceramic powders were used to prepare boroncontaining SiC/HfC dense monoliths (SHBC-SPS) using spark plasma sintering (SPS). The density and open porosity of the SHBC-SPS is ≈ 3.50 g/cm3 and ≈ 0 vol.%, respectively. The powder XRD pattern of the SHBC-SPS is shown in Figure 2. The reflections of HfCxN1-x, βSiC and HfB2 as well as a small peak (at 2θ = 12.16º) assigned to graphite can be analyzed. The weight fractions, grain sizes and lattice parameters of the HfCxN1-x, HfB2 and β-SiC obtained by Full-Profile Rietveld refinement are listed in Table 2. These observations suggest that the dense monolithic SHBS-SPS is a nano/micro composite with HfCxN1-x dispersoids having a wide grain-size range from tens of nanometers to approximately 2.7 micrometers. Moreover, due to the small fraction of HfB2 in SHBC-SPS (< 0.4 wt.%, based on the results of the XRD Rietveld refinement, see Table 2) this phase has not been identified by means of SEM.
The SEM images shown in Figure 10a indicate that the SHC-SPS monoliths exhibit relatively large amount of macropores, suggesting sintering issues during the SPS processing (see white arrows). Owing to the strong covalent bonding of both SiC and HfCxN1-x as well as the resulting rather low self-diffusion coefficients of Si and Hf,[61-65] it is hard to densify SiC/HfC ceramics and completely remove the porosity in a short sintering time (20 min) despite the processing temperature is up to 2200 ºC. However, after incorporation of a small amount of boron via the single-source precursor approach, the SHBC-SPS monoliths have a totally different morphology (Figure 10b). No macropores can be found within the cross section of the SHBCSPS samples, indicating that the SHBC-SPS monolith is fully dense and well sintered. Also, the residual open porosity of SHBC-SPS, measured by the water immersion method, was shown to be negligible (≈ 0).
In section 3.3.1, the elemental analysis shows that the boron content within the amorphous SHBC-1000ºC is ca. 0.5 wt.%, and after annealing at 1900 ºC (i.e., SHBC-1900ºC) the boron content increases to ca. 0.6 wt.% because of the removal of oxygen and nitrogen (Table 1). That means the boron content within the SHBC-SPS monoliths is expected to be in the range of 0.5 ~ 0.6 wt.%. If boron would be fully consumed to form HfB2, the weight fraction of HfB2 in SHBC-SPS should be ca. 4.6 ~ 5.6 wt.%. However, XRD Rietveld refinement shows that the fraction of HfB2 in SHBC-SPS sample is only ca. 0.4 wt.% (Table 2). Moreover, the boron solubility in SiC is less than 0.2 wt.% even at 2500 °C.[17] Thus, most of the boron should be still located in the segregated carbon within the matrix of the SHBC-SPS monoliths. sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: Boron-containing SiC/HfC ceramic nano/micro composites, including powdered samples and dense monoliths, have been prepared successfully using a single-source-precursor approach. In the synthesis step, BH3·SMe2 and Hf(NEt2)4 was used to react with the Si-polymer SMP10 via hydroboration and substitution reactions, respectively, leading to the formation of B- and Hfcontaining single-source precursor. Subsequent thermolysis of the synthesized preceramic polymers resulted in ceramic materials in the Si-Hf-B-C-N system. Microstructural characterization demonstrated that boron was incorporated in the free carbon phase in-situ formed during the pyrolysis process. After annealing at elevated temperatures beyond 1900 °C, the boron-containing carbon reacted with HfCxN1-x to form HfB2. Moreover, the in situ formed boron-containing free carbon phase is considered to act as an effective sintering aid and remarkably enhanced the densification capability of the SiC/HfC nano/micro composites under SPS conditions. The improved densification of the samples resulted in excellent mechanical properties with respect to hardness and Young´s modulus, which exceed those reported for other polymer-derived ceramic nanocomposites.

metadata.abstractText: A boron-containing SiHfC(N,O) amorphous ceramic was synthesized upon pyrolysis of a single-source-precursor at 1000 °C in Ar atmosphere. The high-temperature microstructural evolution of the ceramic at high temperatures was studied using X-ray powder diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. The results show that the ceramic consists of an SiHfC(N,O)-based amorphous matrix and finely dispersed sp-hybridized boron-containing carbon (i.e. ByC).
